Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Mathematics Teacher Transformation Institutes" (MTTI) project is a research-based investigation of how leadership emerges and is expressed through mathematics knowledge, student-focused instructional practices, and influences on schools' mathematics outcomes. In particular, this research is broadening the knowledge base on teaching and learning in mathematics through new understanding of how the study of conceptually-challenging mathematics, particularly in algebra and geometry, benefits second-stage teachers (4-10 years' experience); of how classroom-based action research contributes to critical and analytical understanding of the relationships between teaching practices and student learning; and of how multi-levels of support prepare second-stage teachers for leadership roles.

To achieve these research objectives, the City University of New York (CUNY), Herbert H. Lehman College is partnering with New York City Department of Education Districts 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. Lehman College faculty in mathematics and mathematics education, staff of education centers and institutes who work in Bronx schools, and the Superintendents of Bronx districts work together to engage 80 experienced middle or high school teachers in the Bronx in 330 hours of professional development over 3 years to strengthen their leadership abilities, mathematics abilities, and educational practices. These MTTI teacher participants are further supported on-site at their schools and through on-line discussion forums and are provided opportunities to showcase their work. MTTI cultivates a professional network of mathematics teacher leaders who provide leadership to 200 additional middle and high school mathematics teachers as they enact a variety of roles including mentor, peer coach, presenter, conference participant/speaker, and active member of school curriculum and professional development teams. Additionally, they participate in local and national discussions of current policy, practice, and research, and they develop informed understandings of the strengths and challenges of culturally and linguistically diverse classes. Upon completion of the Institute, participants receive a Certificate for Secondary-School Mathematics Specialists through CUNY's School of Professional Studies of the Graduate School and University Center, registered with New York State Education Department.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematics Teacher Transformation Institutes (MTTI) at Lehman College, The City University of New York, was a six-year MSP program funded by the National Science Foundation. MTTI was designed to support the development of teacher leaders—second-stage Bronx middle and high school teachers with at least four years’ experience. Two cohorts of about 40 teachers each participated in a three-year program that focused on:1) enhancing their knowledge of, appreciation for, and sophistication in mathematics; 2) encouraging use of student-centered teaching through classroom-based inquiry projects; and, 3) building leadership skills and activities. MTTI was a collaborative effort that was directed by a Partnership Leadership Team: faculty in mathematics and mathematics education; leaders of Lehman College’s Institute for Literacy Studies, including the Project Director of its professional-development program, the New York City Mathematics Project; and New York City Department of Education officials. In addition to developing teacher leaders in Bronx schools, MTTI also sought to influence teacher preparation at Lehman College through new courses and innovative pedagogy. The research component of MTTI was intended to broaden the knowledge base on teaching and learning in mathematics through new understanding of how: 1) the study of conceptually-challenging mathematics—particularly in algebra and geometry—benefits second-stage teachers; 2) classroom-based action research contributes to critical and analytical understanding of the relationships between teaching practices and student learning; and, 3) multiple levels of support prepare second-stage teachers for leadership roles.

MTTI recruited two cohorts of about 40 teachers over five years (2009-2011 & 2011-2013). Results from the first cohort showed that there was an increase in their mathematics content knowledge from the beginning to the end of the project.  In addition, there was some indication that there was an increase in both their use of student-centered pedagogy and leadership activities. We also found from Cohort 1 that several participants had limited teacher-leadership experience prior to entering the MTTI project, and that some had few opportunities in their schools to develop their leadership skills. We also discovered that there was confusion on the part of some Cohort 1 participants about the workload that was expected on the various courses.  Also, for the first cohort, the leadership component did not begin until later in the program. These latter findings led to various systemic changes for the second cohort.

We improved our recruitment process for Cohort 2 by articulating more clearly the expectations of the program, and we conducted face-to-face interviews with applicants. We also examined their previous teacher-leadership activities, required a stronger level of support from their principals, and specified more clearly the workload for the various components of the project.  Finally, and perhaps most importantly, we ran the teacher-leadership-development component throughout Cohort 2’s three-year experience.

These changes resulted in an increase in Cohort 2’s mathematics content knowledge. There was a substantial shift away from teacher-centered pedagogy over the course of the two cohorts, an 86% decline from the first to the second.
